flags.title: User-Contributed Project
flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction_rendered:
Tools
  • 1/16" drill bit
  • Clamps
  • Drill gun
  • Duct tape
  • Electronics project box
  • Large step drill
  • Screw gun
  • Spring clamp
  • Spring punch
  • Toaster oven
  • Vacuum cleaner
  • weather seal

lines.text: A - You will need: a vacuum, a toaster oven, a metal project box, a hinged two-picture frame and a metal spring clip.
lines.text_raw: A - You will need: a vacuum, a toaster oven, a metal project box, a hinged two-picture frame and a metal spring clip.

lines.text: B - Drill loads of holes in the top of the metal project box.
lines.text_raw: B - Drill loads of holes in the top of the metal project box.

lines.text: C - Drill a large hole in the side of the project box that is the same diameter as your vacuum hose. I recommend clamping down the box section and using a step drill.
lines.text_raw: C - Drill a large hole in the side of the project box that is the same diameter as your vacuum hose. I recommend clamping down the box section and using a step drill.

lines.text: D - Assemble your project box and seal the seams with duct tape.
lines.text_raw: D - Assemble your project box and seal the seams with duct tape.

lines.text: E- Apply a weather strip to the top perimeter of the box.
lines.text_raw: E- Apply a weather strip to the top perimeter of the box.

lines.text: F - Wrap the vacuum hose with duct tape until it fits in the project box with a good seal.
lines.text_raw: F - Wrap the vacuum hose with duct tape until it fits in the project box with a good seal.

lines.text: G - Remove the glass and backing from the picture frames. Save one backing piece.
lines.text_raw: G - Remove the glass and backing from the picture frames. Save one backing piece.

lines.text: H - Add some wood strips to the frame on the non-hinge side to keep the spring clip from crushing the frame.
lines.text_raw: H - Add some wood strips to the frame on the non-hinge side to keep the spring clip from crushing the frame.

lines.text: I - Use the saved backing piece to mark your plastic sheet.  Shown here is standard .02" thick polystyrene sheet. You can also use the more durable ABS and clear PETG, but it takes a little experimentation to get the timing correct.  Always buy extra material!
lines.text_raw: I - Use the saved backing piece to mark your plastic sheet.  Shown here is standard .02" thick polystyrene sheet. You can also use the more durable ABS and clear PETG, but it takes a little experimentation to get the timing correct.  Always buy extra material!

lines.text: J - insert the plastic sheet into your frame, being sure it seats against the hinges.
lines.text_raw: J - insert the plastic sheet into your frame, being sure it seats against the hinges.

lines.text: K- Close the open end of the frame with the spring clip. (Not shown: Remove the plastic guards from your clip before heating.)
lines.text_raw: K- Close the open end of the frame with the spring clip. (Not shown: Remove the plastic guards from your clip before heating.)

lines.text: L - You can make vacuum form patterns out of any material that won't collapse or get damaged from the heated plastic. I recommend plaster of Paris. It is inexpensive, easy to carve and sands nicely.
lines.text_raw: L - You can make vacuum form patterns out of any material that won't collapse or get damaged from the heated plastic. I recommend plaster of Paris. It is inexpensive, easy to carve and sands nicely.

lines.text: M - You can make a "talc sock" from kid's socks or a cotton rag by pouring talc into the middle of the fabric and closing with a rubberband.
lines.text_raw: M - You can make a "talc sock" from kid's socks or a cotton rag by pouring talc into the middle of the fabric and closing with a rubberband.

lines.text: O - Lightly powder your pattern to keep the plastic from sticking to it.
lines.text_raw: O - Lightly powder your pattern to keep the plastic from sticking to it.

lines.text: P - Preheat your toaster oven set to broil.
lines.text_raw: P - Preheat your toaster oven set to broil.

lines.text: Q - Put on some heavy gloves and hold your plastic close to the top heating element without touching the element. Wait until the plastic droops down about the same distance as the pattern is high.
lines.text_raw: Q - Put on some heavy gloves and hold your plastic close to the top heating element without touching the element. Wait until the plastic droops down about the same distance as the pattern is high.

lines.text: R - Turn on the vacuum. Move the heated plastic onto the top of your pattern while making sure the weather seal makes contact all the way around the frame holding the plastic.
lines.text_raw: R - Turn on the vacuum. Move the heated plastic onto the top of your pattern while making sure the weather seal makes contact all the way around the frame holding the plastic.

lines.text: There you have it!  You've just made your own vacuum forming machine. This project is scalable.  I have made larger machines using a welded frame, space heaters and larger vacuums.
lines.text_raw: There you have it!  You've just made your own vacuum forming machine. This project is scalable.  I have made larger machines using a welded frame, space heaters and larger vacuums.

guide.summary: Here's a quick demo on how to build your own DIY vacuum forming machine with basic items and very little money or experience.
guide.title: Making a DIY Vacuum Former Cheap in One Day
